Frank Drebin.Action: Falls into step alongside the President, smiling to the guests who stare at him in disbelief.
Pulls the chair out for a pretty lady, unintentionally causing Barbara Bush to fall and create a scene.
Goes to aid Barbara Bush after her fall but accidentally hits heads with a Secret Service man.
Feels sorry after accidentally poking Barbara Bush in the eyes with candles.
Pokes a woman's rear end with the candle unintentionally.
Angrily grabs a cigar out of a man's mouth.
Angrily grabs a cigar from a man's mouth and insults him without realizing he is the Cuban Ambassador.
Humbly acknowledges applause and jokingly admits to backing over two drug dealers accidentally.
Leans over to whisper a compliment to Winnie Mandela, though it is awkward and poorly received.
Attempted to eat a huge lobster awkwardly, showing a natural, unpretentious demeanor at a formal gathering.
Unwittingly maneuvers lobster claw near Commissioner's breast, causing her embarrassment while struggling to eat lobster.
Dips pieces of lobster into a lot of butter and accidentally splatters guests, then retrieves the lobster with soaked hands.
Tries to pick up a lemon which squirts out of his buttery hands, showing clumsiness but no malice.
Struggles awkwardly with lobster claws, causing embarrassment and disruption.
Drops lobster into butter dish and gets his hands soaked, creating a mess at an important event.
Fails to pick up a lemon which squirts out of his buttery hands.
Mentioned nostalgically by Jane as someone she cannot forget, suggesting a strong personal impact but no direct demonstration of skill or intelligence in this excerpt.
No direct action or statement by Frank Drebin in this excerpt; no indication of competence or incompetence.
Quickly responds to call about bombing and heads to advise D.C. police.
No direct interaction or intervention shown yet with the bomb situation; dependent on others' findings.
Arrives promptly at the crime scene and observes the scattered bodies and evidence carefully.
Notices unusual chalk outlines on the ceiling and walls, indicating attention to detail.
Casually looks up to notice overlooked clues rather than focusing only at ground level.
Engages in casual conversation about Edna's pregnancy during a critical moment, possibly showing distraction.
No direct action displaying investigative skill beyond observations in this excerpt.
Inquires about other victims and acknowledges standing on a dead body without disrespect.
Winces at the sight of a badly injured victim, indicating empathy.
Insists on handling the questioning of a witness despite objections from a colleague.
Expresses stunned admiration upon seeing Jane, using somewhat objectifying language.
Mistakenly stands on a dead security guard's chest while investigating the scene.
Locates another victim under a blanket, signaling attentiveness to evidence.
Insists on personally questioning a fainted witness despite advice to the contrary.
Gets momentarily stunned and distracted upon seeing Jane, the witness, highlighting a lapse in professional focus.
Politely greets Dr. Meinheimer in a wheelchair, telling him not to get up.
Uncomfortably interacts with Jane, showing lingering bitterness about their past relationship but tries to downplay obsession.
Responds awkwardly and somewhat insensitively about Jane's lack of children and his prostate operation.
Maintains polite social interaction with Dr. Meinheimer by greeting him properly and respecting his wheelchair.
Appears distracted and uncomfortable when interacting with Jane, indicating emotional disturbance.
Attempts to keep conversation light and humorous when addressing emotional topics (e.g., prostate operation, breakup), showing social skill.
Struggles to stay focused and snaps distractedly when Edward calls his attention, revealing lack of self-control.
Tries to encourage despite grim situation, comparing it humorously to a difficult task.
Interrupts the sketch artist and redirects focus away from inappropriate sketches of Jane.
Politely asks permission to look around the Institute, showing respect for others' authority.
Engages with Jane and Ed by asking about the suspect and showing interest in the research lab.
Loses his hard-hat and inadvertently causes sparks and potential damage but discreetly leaves without drawing attention.
Approaches Jane and Meinheimer to inform them that he thinks they ought to know about something, indicating concern or sincerity.
Looks over the rail at delicate machinery, loses his hard-hat which falls into the gears causing sparks, then discreetly exits when a loose gear flies by.
Attempts to gather information from Jane about a suspect and engages with the environment by observing the research area.
Introduces himself with a light, somewhat awkward joke about having used the restrooms, trying to break the ice.
Attempts to respond maturely and defuse tension after being insulted by Quentin, suggesting handling the situation maturely.
Makes a sarcastic and immature insult ('Poopy Pants') towards Quentin during a confrontation.
Responds quickly to an awkward social situation and attempts to defuse tension with humor and maturity.
Makes an odd comment about using the restroom which confuses the other character.
Attempts to stay confident and handle an insult calmly rather than escalating the conflict.
Uses an immature nickname ('Poopy Pants') during a tense confrontation, possibly undermining his authority.
Acknowledges Jane's busy schedule politely and expresses hope she is happy, suggesting consideration for her feelings.
Keeps his hat off to respect circumstances but does not assert himself strongly in the chaotic environment.
Exits quietly without confrontation, possibly indicating respect or avoidance rather than warmth.
Invites Ed to sit with him and share memories, openly discusses his feelings about not fitting in and about Jane.
Mentions thinking about Jane constantly and acknowledges unfairness to other women, demonstrating emotional sincerity and vulnerability.
Orders a complex cocktail but struggles to figure out how to drink it.
Engages in a serious, reflective conversation about his life and relationships, showing emotional insight.
Expresses envy and longing for a lasting, sincere romantic relationship; reveals a desire to love deeply and meaningfully.
Acknowledges his current shallow relationships with twenty-year olds seeking casual encounters, contrasting that with his wish for genuine love.
Goes to Jane’s table with sincerity and openness, indicating a willingness to connect genuinely.
Reflects thoughtfully on love and relationships, expressing genuine emotion and self-awareness.
Gets physically turned around by several people in a bar before sitting down at Jane's table.
Looks into his drink and speaks from the heart expressing loneliness and need for love.
Sits at the wrong table, mistakenly speaking to a confused longshoreman.
Responds to Jane's attempt at reconnecting with sarcasm and mistrust, accusing her insinuating she is involved with her lover boy.
Mistakenly speaks to the wrong person, a confused longshoreman, before realizing his error.
Acknowledges potentially useful information from Jane about the red van across the street, indicating receptiveness to clues.
Directly confronts Jane about their past, showing emotional bluntness but clear communication.
Quickly ends the conversation to move forward with investigation, demonstrating decisiveness.
Jokes about Jane's lover, provoking her to slap him, which could be seen as poor interpersonal tact.
Intercepts Jane's slap, holds her wrist gently instead of retaliating.
Makes sarcastic comments about his rainforest purchase and displacing a tribe, showing lack of empathy.
Responds insensitively to Jane's emotional expressions, fails to acknowledge her feelings.
Calls out Jane when she leaves, tries to engage her, though awkwardly.
Embraces his single status humorously and somewhat proudly in front of others, possibly masking loneliness.
Exhibits loneliness and sadness walking alone while seeing loving couples, indicating deeper emotional vulnerability.
Makes his way through a crowd of passionate lovers, carefully picking his way through the chaotic scene without causing disruption.
Seems unable to understand where everyone is coming from, implying confusion about the situation.
Opens the door and unintentionally knocks out the drug-crazed maniac, allowing the police to subdue him and save others.
Is oblivious to the tense hostage situation he inadvertently resolves.
Shows genuine interest and polite engagement when Ted presents the scientific findings.
Drives carelessly, rear-ending a car and triggering a chain reaction that damages a cement truck and floods an unoccupied police car with cement, while being preoccupied and oblivious.
Accidentally knocks out an armed drug-crazed maniac by opening a door, allowing police to subdue him, but remains unaware of his effective action.
Asks about lab results with apparent confidence and interest after a tense incident, showing some engagement in the investigation.
Expresses interest and enthusiasm in Ted's archaeological findings, acknowledges Ted's work respectfully.
Engages in friendly, casual conversation reminiscing about boxing figures with others, showing sociability and shared knowledge.
Recognizes the name Hector Savage and recalls details about the boxer, demonstrating knowledge and confident recall.
Corrects Nordberg about the boxer’s location, demonstrating attentive knowledge and willingness to clarify facts.
Makes a dismissive, humorous comment about boxing bets, showing casual confidence but not necessarily professional competence.
Responds to Ed's leery insinuation with a polite refusal and redirects focus to work.
Recognizes the significance of the address in the Red Light District, showing situational awareness.
Leery of Ed's intentions, chooses to stay focused on work, maintaining professionalism.
Uses the given lead (Monique DeCarlo's address) to attempt to track down Hector Savage, demonstrating investigative skill.
Attempts to handle and deactivate strange devices in the sex shop, including turning off a noisy mechanical device after it grabs his tie.
Asks how to use a large leaf blower and correctly identifies it as a gardener's tool, demonstrating some observational skill.
Engages in somewhat awkward and evasive conversation with Monique about their intentions, showing limited social or investigative skill.
Declares himself as 'the last line of defense between sleaze like this and the decent people of this town!' when confronted nastily by Monique.
Confidently demands information about Hector Savage and asserts himself as a protector of decency.
Remarks on 'Portuguese Butt Blaster' with some confusion but follows up appropriately.
Analyzes the situation at the window and concludes Savage is playing into their hands, showing tactical insight.
Monitors the radar screen intently, correctly interprets Nordberg's movements, and instructs Ed to increase speed accordingly.
Fails to immediately see Nordberg rolling backward down the street behind them.
Drives up to the crack house with Ed and quickly takes charge by flashing his badge to the police sergeant in a tense situation.
Does not show hesitation or confusion when approaching the tense crime scene surrounded by multiple police units and a SWAT presence.
Allows Nordberg to get stuck under a bus and in danger of diesel exhaust, showing lack of immediate control over the team's safety.
Slaps a nervous cop on the back in a friendly manner.
Shows smug attitude ('Well, it looks like the cows have come home to roost.') in a tense situation.
Displays smug confidence upon recognizing van registration and references it colloquially ('the cows have come home to roost').
Slaps a nervous cop on the back who then accidentally fires, triggering a chaotic shootout involving all officers including himself.
Takes control of situation by requesting and using the bullhorn to address the hostage taker directly with clear instructions, demonstrating initiative.

Gives a confusing and somewhat contradictory hostage surrender instruction ('Throw down your guns and come on out, or come on out then throw down your guns. Whichever way you want to do it.') potentially reducing clarity.
Confidently takes control of an urban assault vehicle without official clearance, reassuring Ed to 'just keep him busy.'
Climbs into an urban assault battering ram without prior clearance or being checked out on it, confidently takes control and approaches the target house.
Uses the battering ram's mechanical arm to ring the doorbell and intimidate the suspect, successfully cornering Savage inside the house.
Continues to operate the battering ram despite limited visibility and chaos caused by the escape of the suspect and zoo animals.
Politely accepts assistance from the butler with his coat and shows good-natured trust by having a receipt ready.
Follows Commissioner Brumford upstairs without hesitation, demonstrating trust and respectful demeanor.
His facial expression shows confusion or surprise ('what the hell happened?'), indicating a sincere and open emotional response.
Greets Commissioner Brumford with a compliment, calling her 'lovely tonight.'
Responds to Commissioner's anger with a sarcastic remark blaming voters for the baboon escape.
Politely taps the gentleman dancing with Jane to ask to cut in, asking 'May I?'
Approaches Commissioner Brumford calmly and greets her politely despite her anger.
Attempts a witty retort blaming the voters for the baboon escape incident in response to the Commissioner's anger.
Quickly notices the musical fanfare during a tense moment, showing situational awareness.
Cuts in on Jane while she is dancing by tapping the other man on the back and asking politely.
Taps a gentleman on the back to cut in and dance with Jane.
Shows a lot of attitude and confidence while dancing, putting on a display that draws applause.
Expresses suspicion and distrust toward Quentin Hapsburg, calling him dirty and insinuating criminal connections.
Dances closely with Jane and uses the moment to manipulate the situation by provoking jealousy in Quentin.
Smiles smugly when led to Hapsburg's table, showing confidence but not warmth.
Makes a lighthearted joke about gambling ('Every time I order out.'), showing a friendly and good-natured demeanor.
Responds to the invitation to drink and play games with witty, amiable remarks, e.g. 'Chances are for kamikaze pilots' and 'I do kiss that way.'
Engages socially with Hapsburg and Jane, maintaining polite and humorous interaction.
Smiles smugly when being invited to join Hapsburg, indicating confidence in social situations and interaction with the antagonist's circle.
Responds with witty remarks during conversation with Hapsburg, shows quick thinking but with a comedic tone.
Sits down to play a game of chance despite previous quip about kamikaze pilots, indicating willingness to engage strategically.
Fails to impress or intimidate Hapsburg or extract useful information directly from the yearbook picture.
Attempts to help (Fake) Meinheimer by pushing his wheelchair to the podium.
Overanxious to correct a mistake when the wheelchair jams and spills hot coffee on (Fake) Meinheimer.
Causes chaos accidentally by mishandling the wheelchair controls, injuring himself and (Fake) Meinheimer in the process.
Overanxiously attempts to correct the wheelchair's jam but causes a scalding injury and exacerbates the situation, resulting in chaos.
Attempts to control the wheelchair using the lever but inadvertently puts it into 'Reverse,' causing further havoc.
Tries to call after Jane as she rushes out in tears, showing concern for her feelings.
Brings Jane a large bouquet despite half of it being destroyed, indicating an attempt to make amends or show affection.
Desperately tries to stop the runaway wheelchair by reaching for the control lever and pushing it forward to 'Forward-Hi' setting.
Fails to hang on to the wheelchair as it does a wheelie and speeds dangerously across the dance floor, causing chaos and endangering guests.
Tries to call after Jane as she rushes out tearfully, showing some emotional awareness but no evident competence in resolving the situation.
Transports an extremely large bouquet, half of which is damaged just bringing it out of the car, indicating clumsiness or lack of skill.
Brings a large bouquet to Jane as an apology, expressing remorse for earlier embarrassment.
Asks to come inside and engages politely with Jane, compliments her apartment sincerely.
Struggles to carry and protect a very large, bulky bouquet, which becomes damaged in the process.
Attempts to apologize sincerely to Jane despite apparently having embarrassed himself earlier.
Enters Jane's apartment respectfully and tries to engage in polite conversation, noticing and commenting on the environment.
Fails to communicate effectively when a train noise drowns out his voice, then declines to repeat himself, possibly giving up on an important communication.
Declines Jane's offer for a protein shake but engages her in conversation politely.
Recognizes Jane's insight and compliments her idea as 'brilliant' and better than his own.
Quickly pours his unwanted drink back into the blender to avoid drinking it.
Tosses the drink out the window to avoid drinking it, ignoring possible disturbance.
Quickly realizes the suspicious changes in Dr. Meinheimer and connects the dots about the double and fraudulent report.
Reluctantly drinks Jane's odd protein shake and then quickly discards it upon realizing its unpleasantness.
Shows surprise and admits that Jane's insight is better than his own plan, indicating openness and adaptability.
Tells Jane she is hurting him when she grips his arm tightly.
Allows Jane to leave and let herself out after asking to use the phone.
Asks to use the phone politely and waits for Jane to leave rather than acting impulsively.
Appears unsure or vulnerable when Jane grips his arm and calls him jealous, showing emotional distraction.
Attempts to call Ed Hocken but is met with insipid hold music, indicating limited progress in communication.
Bursts into bathroom to wrestle gun away from Savage and protect Jane.
Pauses to look at naked Jane along with Savage during struggle.
Uses a hair dryer to blow hot air in Savage's face, causing him pain.
Carries out a flying tackle after Savage, causing a physical struggle that inconveniences an elderly lady and her poodle.
Struggles with Savage while their heads are caught in elevator doors, showing persistence despite discomfort.
Uses a fire hose nozzle to choke Savage and then inadvertently causes distress by over-filling Savage's stomach with water, and attempts to fix it by turning off the water.
Uses a hair dryer to blow hot air in the attacker's face to disorient him.
Recovers from having a towel thrown in his face and immediately pursues the attacker.
Successfully tackles the fleeing attacker despite distractions.
Uses a fire hose as an improvised weapon to subdue attacker.
Unable to remove the fire hose nozzle stuck in the attacker's throat and loses control of the water pressure, leading to a dangerous and uncontrollable situation.
Expresses panic and lack of a clear plan when the situation with the water-filled attacker escalates.
Reads and interprets the dock pass to deduce the possible identity of the attacker and location linked to the threat.
Reassures Jane with calmness and attempts to comfort her despite the stressful situation.
Initially panics slightly when noticing Savage is 'ballooning' and under pressure.
Dismisses Jane's question about what happened with a vague 'nothing' which could indicate withholding information or lack of full control over the situation.
Responds seriously to Jane’s distress about Dr. Meinheimer's danger and hostage situation, showing concern.
Reassures Jane he will be careful when going to help, showing consideration for her feelings.
Mentions baking raisin-nut bread with Nordberg, indicating friendly social engagement.
Physically comforts Jane by allowing her to bury her head on his shoulder and engages in intimate activity, showing warmth and affection.
Reasonably deduces that Dr. Meinheimer is being held hostage in a warehouse based on a hunch and the dock pass.
Attempts to reassure Jane he will be careful, but quickly makes an excuse to leave, suggesting a lack of preparedness or confidence.
Demonstrates strong, confident presence that impacts Jane emotionally.
Responds to Ed's concerns about the mission by affirming their duty to stop criminal activity despite risks.
Struggles and overexerts himself putting on a tight wetsuit, showing determination to carry out his responsibilities.
Asserts confidently that they have a job to do despite objections, showing determination and sense of duty.
Struggles to get his leg into the wet suit, pulls it hard until it stretches beyond limits and then it shoots off his foot.
Encourages team with 'When I say I love it, then you guys move in' to signal action.
Gives Prank a thumbs-up to encourage before he jumps.
Fails backwards off the boat accidentally but stays calm.
Practices near water and attempts to enter a secured perimeter despite encountering snarling Dobermans, showing persistence and situational awareness.
Looks for alternate ways inside after being blocked by dogs instead of charging or panicking.
Uses a grappling hook gun skillfully to access a roof by shooting it accurately and climbing up confidently.
Faces a snarling, frothing dog nose-to-nose despite fear, showing courage and possibly concern.
Lets go of the rope to protect 'Prank' from the chasing dog.
Runs through a skylight, breaks table, but stands up dusted off and clean despite surrounded by armed thugs.
Offers to skip torture by sarcastically suggesting he crawl over and kiss boots.
Attempts to maintain a positive attitude by saying 'I love it' despite swimming in raw sewage.
Gulps, realizing he's in a bad spot now (showing awareness of danger).
Responds calmly and sarcastically to threats by suggesting he could skip the pain and go straight to kissing boots.
Acknowledges foul odor by openly admitting he has been swimming in raw sewage and tries to project confidence.
Allows a goon to search him thoroughly without apparent resistance or preventative measures.
Fails to prevent capture or escape as the van doors do not open and they are trapped.
Maintains composure and remains defiant when faced with danger and captivity, telling Hapsburg 'You'll never get away with this.'
Speaks politely and tough in a tense situation, e.g. 'The pleasure's all mine' in response to a threat.
Maintains composure and speaks defiantly to captors despite being tied up.
Allows himself to be tied up without apparent resistance or escape attempt.
Switches on the TV set to stay informed while captive.
Notices a hacksaw just behind his hands while tied up and tries to reach it by shaking the shelf back and forth.
Spots a hacksaw behind his hands on the shelf while tied up and attempts to reach it by shaking the shelf back and forth.
Distracts by telling a goon to 'Keep your eye on the gorilla' while attempting escape.
Is tied up and restrained, seemingly unable to free himself quickly without external help.
Feels embarrassed and gently tries to break up Ed's violent retaliation.
Gives up on using the hacksaw after accidentally causing harm to Dr. Meinheimer.
Attempts to reach the hacksaw to presumably help; tries to intervene in a difficult, chaotic situation.
Gives up with the hacksaw after causing unintended harm to Dr. Meinheimer (tarred and feathered, unconscious).
Seems embarrassed and hesitant when trying to break in and stop Ed's violent outburst.
Orders to cuff the beaten suspect and prioritize urgent duties by directing help for the Captain and heading to the Press Club Dinner.
Instructs Jane to meet them at the hotel rear entrance and expresses hope she can avoid danger.
Knocks repeatedly on the door when Jane does not respond, showing concern.
Takes initiative to involve others (approach mariachi band) to find a way forward when stuck.
Coordinates meeting point with Jane and team, shows awareness of situation regarding Hapsburg.
Knocks on door repeatedly with no response, does not immediately take further investigative action.
Quickly notices nearby mariachi band and uses police authority to detain them as possible suspects or for investigation.
Joins his team in donning ridiculous mariachi outfits and performing music to entertain guests despite awkwardness.
Responds politely and cooperatively to hotel manager's reprimand without argument or complaint.
Dresses up in ridiculous mariachi outfits and awkwardly performs music for guests, freezing initially but then getting into the song, producing a nearly listenable performance.
Sings humorously and confidently to engage the crowd, demonstrating a lighthearted and approachable manner.
Removes disguise and confronts imposter directly, showing sincerity and straightforwardness.
Yanks the helpless Meinheimer out of his wheelchair and starts pummeling him.
Removes multiple prostheses disguising himself, demonstrating preparation and resourcefulness.
Grabs Meinheimer by the lapels and hoists him out of the wheelchair, showing physical assertiveness and control.
Gets beaten by bystanders after appearing to assault a man in a wheelchair, indicating poor situational awareness and misjudgment.
Despite being semi-conscious and injured, springs to his feet and continues to confront Meinheimer.
Pummels Meinheimer, drawing attention and provoking bystanders to intervene against him, highlighting lack of control over a situation.
Is surrounded and beaten up by bystanders, remains groggy and unconscious.
Police officer Ed tries to revive him, indicating Frank is incapacitated and not actively handling the situation.
Rushes on stage to expose a fraud despite chaos, showing determination to reveal the truth.
Rips down a man's pants publicly, causing embarrassment to reveal a birthmark.
Uses a brillo pad and later a drill sander on the man's exposed behind in a misguided attempt to prove forgery, creating an appalling scene.
Bolts for the stage quickly to stop a fraud before the audience.
Attempts to prove the impostor's identity by revealing a birthmark, showing awareness and some investigative intent.
Misidentifies the birthmark as the 'Whistler's Mother' birthmark, indicating a lack of correct knowledge.
Uses inappropriate methods (scrubbing with a brillo pad, then attempting to remove a tattoo with a drill sander) to demonstrate the forgery, causing embarrassment and chaos.
Fails to control the situation on stage, resulting in public scandal and near arrest.
Responds immediately to a threat against Jane by shooting back at the assailants, showing protective and courageous behavior.
Engages in a gunfight with the goon who is threatening Jane, indicating his willingness to risk himself for others.
Ducks behind a garbage can quickly after a bullet ricochets inches from his head, then fires back at the assailants.
Engages in a gunfight at close range with an armed goon, actively shooting.
Throws his gun at the goon after the goon throws his empty gun at him.
Kneels by wounded goon and carefully removes his knee from the injured area on goon's groin.
Commands thugs aggressively and insults them ('lowlife scum!'), threatening them to get information.
Charges in firing two guns simultaneously a la Butch Cassidy, showing confident and proactive combat behavior.
Asks the wounded goon pointed questions to gain tactical information, demonstrating situational awareness and interrogation skills.
Carefully moves knee off the wounded goon’s groin on realizing the pain, showing some consideration and quick adjustment.
Despite attempts to interrogate multiple thugs, the information received is confusing and incomplete, and thugs die before providing clear direction.
Drops his gun without resistance when Jane is held hostage.
Remains calm and thinks fast when threatened with a nuclear device.
Defiantly challenges Hapsburg's threats despite the danger to innocent people.
Drops his gun immediately when ordered, showing compliance under threat.
Is shocked but thinking fast in response to Hapsburg's nuclear threat.
Responds confidently and defiantly to Hapsburg's threat despite the danger.
Uses humor and sarcasm in a tense situation (jokes about Hapsburg and missing bike seat).
Physically fights to disarm opponent and protect control panel.
Tricks Hapsburg into lowering the gun, then swiftly grabs it during their struggle.
Uses verbal taunts to unsettle the opponent before taking action.
Confidently instructs Hapsburg to operate the control panel after disarming her.
Initially falls for a trick when Hapsburg gestures with the gun to misdirect him.
Rushes to untie and check on Jane after the threat of detonation.
Expresses concern for Jane's safety and insists she leaves with Ed for her protection.
Shows hesitation about Jane staying with him despite the danger, indicating care for her wellbeing.
Responds to Jane's offer to help and jokes about a nice loofah bath.
Looks at Jane with a look that implies mild reprimand when she triggers an alarm.
Attempts to disarm a complicated bomb by interacting with the machine, presses buttons, and tries to follow instructions.
Shows frustration when the alarm speeds up detonation after following instructions from the booklet.
Maintains some level of calm and attempts to guide Jane who is reading the instructions, seeking relevant info to save them.
Attempts to awaken comatose delegates by showing them a risqué paperback to snap them out of anesthesia.
Politely declines the President's offer despite potential pressure or expectation.
Compares love to the ozone layer, expressing a sentimental and sincere view of love and loss.
Expresses a heartfelt desire for a better world where people can live peacefully and simply, mentioning universal hopes and love.
Publicly declares love for Jane and joyfully embraces her upon her acceptance of his proposal.
Mistakenly puts his arm around the wrong person (Barbara Bush) but politely apologizes.
Delivers a public speech that resonates with the audience, earning hearty applause and positive reaction.
Makes a social faux pas by awkwardly putting his arm around the wrong person (Barbara Bush) and quickly apologizing.
Shows emotional intelligence by expressing sincere sentiments about love and the environment, connecting well with Jane and the audience.
Frank and Jane exit the church and are celebrated by a joyous crowd that throws confetti and rice cakes, including friends and colleagues.
